screens.headline: $10K account ‚â† 10 contracts. Here's why.
screens.text: You have $10,000. You try to sell 10 cash-secured puts at $100 strike. Your broker rejects it: 'Insufficient buying power.' But 10 √ó $100 = $1,000... right? Wrong. Each CSP requires $10,000 reserved. You can sell ONE contract, not ten. Let's learn how buying power actually works.

screens.headline: What is Buying Power?
screens.text: BUYING POWER = the capital your broker RESERVES for each position. Not the same as your account balance. BUYING options = pay premium (small). SELLING options = tie up capital (large). Each strategy has different requirements. Max out buying power = margin call risk.

cards.definition: Amount of capital reserved/locked when you open a position
cards.example: Sell $50 put = $5,000 BPR (you need $5,000 available). Your $10k account can only do 2 contracts.
$350 strike √ó 100 = $35,000 reserved per contract. Need full amount in cash.

cards.definition: Must OWN 100 shares of stock (no additional cash needed)
cards.example: Own 100 AAPL = can sell 1 call. Own 500 shares = 5 calls max. Stock = the collateral.
$45-$50 put spread = $5 width √ó 100 = $500 reserved. Much less than naked put!

screens.headline: Think of it like your credit card limit

reveal_sections.label: Buying a $200 item (buying options)
reveal_sections.content: $200 charge on $10,000 limit = $9,800 available credit left. You PAID $200, simple. Buying options works this way - you pay premium, that's it.

reveal_sections.label: Holding authorization (selling options)
reveal_sections.content: Hotel puts $2,000 HOLD on card for incidentals. You didn't spend it, but it's RESERVED. Only $8,000 available now. Selling CSPs works this way - cash is reserved, not spent.

reveal_sections.label: Multiple holds = maxed out
reveal_sections.content: Five hotels √ó $2,000 hold = $10,000 reserved. Card declines at restaurant even though you haven't spent anything! This is why you can't sell 10 CSPs with $10k - buying power is RESERVED.

Try buying options: Minimal buying power needed

screens.question: You have $25,000. You want to sell cash-secured puts on a $50 stock. How many contracts can you sell?
screens.explanation_correct: Perfect math! Each $50 CSP requires $50 √ó 100 shares = $5,000 reserved. $25,000 √∑ $5,000 = 5 contracts maximum. Each contract ties up $5,000 even though premium might only be $200. The $5,000 is RESERVED for potential assignment, not spent!
screens.explanation_wrong: Cash-secured puts require FULL strike price reserved. $50 strike √ó 100 shares = $5,000 per contract. Your $25,000 √∑ $5,000 = 5 contracts max. Premium collected ($200-300) is separate - the $5,000 must stay reserved in case you're assigned!

screens.question: You have $30,000 and sell 5 CSPs at $50 strike ($5,000 each = $25,000 reserved). Then stock drops and you're assigned on all 5. What happens?
options: You need MORE money - margin call!
You now own 500 shares, paid for with your $25,000 reserve
screens.explanation_correct: Exactly how it works! Your $25,000 reserve gets USED to buy 500 shares at $50/share. You now own 500 shares (market value maybe $45/share = $22,500) and have $5,000 cash left. You're underwater $2,500 but fully paid - no margin call. The reserve was there for this reason!
screens.explanation_wrong: This is WHY it's called 'cash-secured' - you RESERVED the $25,000 for this! When assigned, that $25,000 buys your 500 shares at $50/share. No margin call, no surprise. You now own stock and can sell covered calls. The system worked as designed!

screens.question: Which strategy uses the LEAST buying power?
screens.explanation_correct: Correct! BUYING options = pay premium upfront ($500 for this call), done. No reserves needed. Buying power used = just the premium. SELLING options = huge reserves ($5,000-10,000). This is why buying options is easier for small accounts!
screens.explanation_wrong: BUYING options uses minimal buying power (just the premium paid). SELLING options ties up massive capital. $5 call = $500 paid, that's it. $100 CSP = $10,000 reserved! Small accounts should BUY options, not sell them.

screens.question: Your account: $50,000. You want to sell $100 CSPs. How many should you actually sell?
screens.explanation_correct: Smart risk management! $50k √∑ $10k = 5 max, but pros leave 20-30% cushion. Sell 3-4 contracts = $30-40k used, $10-20k available. Why? Opportunities arise, margin requirements can change, emergency exits. Never max out buying power - leave breathing room!
screens.explanation_wrong: Never max out buying power! Yes, you CAN sell 5 contracts ($50k capacity), but SHOULD sell 3-4. Leave $10-15k available (20-30% cushion) for: new opportunities, emergency adjustments, margin requirement changes, peace of mind. Maxed out = trapped, can't maneuver!

screens.question: What's the danger of maxing out your buying power?
options: You can't open new positions or adjustments
Your broker will close your positions
There's no danger - use it all!
screens.explanation_correct: Exactly the trap! Maxed out = paralyzed. Position going against you? Can't roll. Great opportunity appears? Can't take it. Market drops, margins increase? Forced liquidations. Always keep 20-30% buying power available. Flexibility = survival in options trading!
screens.explanation_wrong: Maxed out buying power = no flexibility. Can't adjust losing trades, can't take new opportunities, can't handle margin increases. It's like driving cross-country on empty tank - one problem and you're stranded. Keep 20-30% available always!

cards.front: How much buying power does each strategy need?
cards.back: BUYING options: Just premium ($200-500). SELLING CSPs: Strike √ó 100 ($5,000-10,000). Covered calls: Own stock (no cash). Spreads: Width √ó 100 ($500-1,000). Know these before trading!

cards.front: How many contracts can I trade?
cards.back: Account Balance √∑ Buying Power Per Contract = Max Contracts. Example: $25,000 √∑ $5,000 CSP = 5 contracts max. But DON'T max out - use only 3-4 (70-80% of capacity).
1) Roll/adjust losing positions, 2) Take new opportunities, 3) Handle margin changes, 4) Emergency exits, 5) Peace of mind. Maxed out = trapped. Flexibility = survival!
